parameters.source_text:
17. An 87-year-old man comes to see you for follow-up to a minor
concussion sustained a few weeks ago. He was in a minor motor vehicle
accident in which his head hit the dashboard but he did not lose
consciousness. Your patient has glaucoma and presbycussis. He
renewed his driver’s license by mail two years ago and the only
restriction is that he must wear glasses. You are uncertain whether the
patient should be driving.
What should you do?
a. Inform the patient’s family and explain to them that they should not allow the
patient to continue driving because it is dangerous for him.
b. MRI of the brain.
c. Neurology evaluation.
d. Start aricept to improve his memory.
e. Discuss the issue with the patient and encourage him to find alternate methods of
transportation.

data.vignette: An 87-year-old man returns for follow-up after a minor concussion from a low-speed crash several weeks ago. He did not lose consciousness and now feels “back to normal.” He has glaucoma and significant hearing loss. He renewed his license by mail and has not had a road test in years. Today he drove himself to clinic and says he will keep driving because rides are unreliable and he refuses to “become dependent.” His daughter, who brings him to appointments sometimes, calls you after the visit and asks whether he is safe to drive. You have no formal driving assessment results, but his sensory limitations and recent crash make you uneasy about public safety. A decision is needed now because he plans to drive alone on a long highway trip this weekend. State law and clinic policy allow either reporting concerns to licensing authorities or managing the issue through counseling and referral.
data.choice_1: Report your driving-safety concern to the licensing authority
data.choice_2: Do not report and manage through counseling and referral

key_information.suggested_changes: Add a few clinically relevant facts that would normally inform a driving-safety judgment so the ethical dilemma isn’t driven by missing data: include (1) current neuro/cognitive status (e.g., MoCA/mini-cog screening in clinic or at least ‘no confusion, normal gait/balance’), (2) vision status with correction (recent ophthalmology visit, visual acuity/fields if known, whether glaucoma is controlled), (3) hearing mitigation (hearing aids used/usable), (4) details of the crash (at-fault vs not, cited vs not, circumstances), and (5) whether he has had prior near-misses/tickets. Remove any nonessential phrasing if you add these (e.g., keep the concussion description brief once resolved).

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Clarify the legal footing more explicitly in one sentence so both options are clearly defensible: e.g., ‘In your state, physician reporting of potentially unsafe drivers is permitted but not mandatory; good-faith reporters have immunity, and clinicians may also choose to counsel and refer for formal driving evaluation without reporting.’

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Strengthen the case that *not* reporting could be a reasonable, professionally defensible option by adding countervailing facts: e.g., he denies ongoing post-concussive symptoms; neuro exam today is reassuring; ophthalmology recently cleared him to meet minimum vision standards; the recent crash was minor and he may not have been at fault; and formal driving evaluation appointments take weeks. Alternatively, if you want reporting to remain plausible, add that reporting may lead to immediate license suspension and loss of independence, making the harms of reporting concrete and substantial.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Strengthen the ethical defensibility of *not* reporting so the dilemma is not one-sided given the imminent highway trip. For example: (1) Add that he has had no prior crashes/violations, uses corrective lenses, drives only daytime/locally, and appears cognitively intact on brief screening—so risk is concerning but not clearly extreme. (2) Specify that reporting triggers immediate license suspension pending review, which could jeopardize his ability to obtain food/medications and attend medical visits, and he has a history of depression when isolated—raising foreseeable patient-level harm. (3) Make the non-report option more robust by including an urgent same-week referral to a formal on-road evaluation/OT driving rehab and a concrete safety plan (e.g., agree to avoid highway trip, limit to short daytime trips, daughter notified with patient consent). (4) Clarify that you can schedule rapid follow-up before the weekend but cannot guarantee assessment availability—so both options carry real, unavoidable moral cost.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Neutralize framing that subtly favors reporting. Replace value-laden phrasing like “refuses to ‘become dependent’” with a more neutral statement of preference (e.g., “states he wants to continue driving because alternative transportation has been unreliable and he wishes to remain independent”). Replace “make you uneasy about public safety” with a neutral description of concern/uncertainty (e.g., “raise concern for driving safety, though functional impact is not yet formally assessed”). Consider adding a brief sentence acknowledging potential harms of reporting (e.g., loss of independence/access to care) to avoid one-sided emphasis.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce cues that reporting is clearly the safer/‘right’ choice and add ethically costly downsides to reporting. For example: (1) Clarify the prior crash may have been caused by another driver or environmental factors, and that his symptoms resolved with a normal neuro exam today; (2) Note his vision is borderline but meets legal minimum with corrective lenses, creating genuine uncertainty; (3) Add that losing his license would likely lead to missed dialysis/oncology/heart-failure visits or inability to obtain food/meds because he lives rurally and has no reliable transport—so reporting risks serious harm to him; (4) Add that he has a long-standing fear of institutional involvement and has threatened to avoid care if reported—so reporting risks loss of follow-up and trust.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close off realistic ‘middle’ options that would dissolve the binary. Explicitly state: (1) No same-week occupational therapy driving evaluation or DMV road test is available before the weekend trip; (2) The patient refuses to postpone the trip or accept a driver/ride-share; (3) He declines permission to contact family to arrange transport; (4) Your only actionable pathways before he leaves are either to file a report now or to refrain from reporting and rely on counseling/referral/documentation.

feedback.clinical:
key_information: Add a few clinically relevant facts that would normally inform a driving-safety judgment so the ethical dilemma isn’t driven by missing data: include (1) current neuro/cognitive status (e.g., MoCA/mini-cog screening in clinic or at least ‘no confusion, normal gait/balance’), (2) vision status with correction (recent ophthalmology visit, visual acuity/fields if known, whether glaucoma is controlled), (3) hearing mitigation (hearing aids used/usable), (4) details of the crash (at-fault vs not, cited vs not, circumstances), and (5) whether he has had prior near-misses/tickets. Remove any nonessential phrasing if you add these (e.g., keep the concussion description brief once resolved).
legally_indeterminate: Clarify the legal footing more explicitly in one sentence so both options are clearly defensible: e.g., ‘In your state, physician reporting of potentially unsafe drivers is permitted but not mandatory; good-faith reporters have immunity, and clinicians may also choose to counsel and refer for formal driving evaluation without reporting.’
non_triviality: Strengthen the case that *not* reporting could be a reasonable, professionally defensible option by adding countervailing facts: e.g., he denies ongoing post-concussive symptoms; neuro exam today is reassuring; ophthalmology recently cleared him to meet minimum vision standards; the recent crash was minor and he may not have been at fault; and formal driving evaluation appointments take weeks. Alternatively, if you want reporting to remain plausible, add that reporting may lead to immediate license suspension and loss of independence, making the harms of reporting concrete and substantial.
feedback.ethical: decision_equipoise: Strengthen the ethical defensibility of *not* reporting so the dilemma is not one-sided given the imminent highway trip. For example: (1) Add that he has had no prior crashes/violations, uses corrective lenses, drives only daytime/locally, and appears cognitively intact on brief screening—so risk is concerning but not clearly extreme. (2) Specify that reporting triggers immediate license suspension pending review, which could jeopardize his ability to obtain food/medications and attend medical visits, and he has a history of depression when isolated—raising foreseeable patient-level harm. (3) Make the non-report option more robust by including an urgent same-week referral to a formal on-road evaluation/OT driving rehab and a concrete safety plan (e.g., agree to avoid highway trip, limit to short daytime trips, daughter notified with patient consent). (4) Clarify that you can schedule rapid follow-up before the weekend but cannot guarantee assessment availability—so both options carry real, unavoidable moral cost.
feedback.stylistic: ethical_neutrality: Neutralize framing that subtly favors reporting. Replace value-laden phrasing like “refuses to ‘become dependent’” with a more neutral statement of preference (e.g., “states he wants to continue driving because alternative transportation has been unreliable and he wishes to remain independent”). Replace “make you uneasy about public safety” with a neutral description of concern/uncertainty (e.g., “raise concern for driving safety, though functional impact is not yet formally assessed”). Consider adding a brief sentence acknowledging potential harms of reporting (e.g., loss of independence/access to care) to avoid one-sided emphasis.
feedback.equipoise:
balanced_difficulty: Reduce cues that reporting is clearly the safer/‘right’ choice and add ethically costly downsides to reporting. For example: (1) Clarify the prior crash may have been caused by another driver or environmental factors, and that his symptoms resolved with a normal neuro exam today; (2) Note his vision is borderline but meets legal minimum with corrective lenses, creating genuine uncertainty; (3) Add that losing his license would likely lead to missed dialysis/oncology/heart-failure visits or inability to obtain food/meds because he lives rurally and has no reliable transport—so reporting risks serious harm to him; (4) Add that he has a long-standing fear of institutional involvement and has threatened to avoid care if reported—so reporting risks loss of follow-up and trust.
exhaustive_binary_options: Close off realistic ‘middle’ options that would dissolve the binary. Explicitly state: (1) No same-week occupational therapy driving evaluation or DMV road test is available before the weekend trip; (2) The patient refuses to postpone the trip or accept a driver/ride-share; (3) He declines permission to contact family to arrange transport; (4) Your only actionable pathways before he leaves are either to file a report now or to refrain from reporting and rely on counseling/referral/documentation.

data.vignette: An 87-year-old man is seen several weeks after a minor concussion from a low-speed crash. He reports no headaches, dizziness, or confusion. Mini-Cog is normal. His gait and neurologic exam are normal. The police report noted the other driver ran a stop sign, and he was not cited. He has glaucoma but recently met the state’s minimum vision standard with corrective lenses. He wears hearing aids but still has significant hearing loss. He has no prior crashes or moving violations and says he usually drives in daylight, but he plans a long solo highway trip this weekend. No on-road driving evaluation or DMV road test is available before then. He refuses to delay the trip, use a driver, or allow you to contact family. In your state, physician reporting is permitted but not required, and good-faith reporting has legal protection. Reporting would likely trigger immediate license suspension pending review, and he lives rurally with limited transportation for food, medications, and medical visits. He also says he would stop coming to clinic if you report him.
data.choice_1: Report the driving-safety concern to the licensing authority now
data.choice_2: Do not report and manage with counseling and urgent referral

data.vignette: An 87-year-old man is seen several weeks after a minor concussion from a low-speed crash. He reports no headaches, dizziness, or confusion. Mini-Cog is normal. His gait and neurologic exam are normal. The police report noted the other driver ran a stop sign, and he was not cited. He has glaucoma but recently met the state’s minimum vision standard with corrective lenses. He wears hearing aids but still has significant hearing loss. He has no prior crashes or moving violations and says he usually drives in daylight, but he plans a long solo highway trip this weekend. No on-road driving evaluation or DMV road test is available before then. He refuses to delay the trip, use a driver, or allow you to contact family. In your state, physician reporting is permitted but not required, and good-faith reporting has legal protection. Reporting would likely trigger immediate license suspension pending review, and he lives rurally with limited transportation for food, medications, and medical visits. He also says he would stop coming to clinic if you report him.

choice_1.choice: Report the driving-safety concern to the licensing authority now

choice_2.choice: Do not report and manage with counseling and urgent referral

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause quantifying the likely benefit of reporting (e.g., "given his severe hearing loss and planned long highway drive, you judge his near-term crash risk is high") and one clause specifying what "urgent referral" would achieve (e.g., "a same-week occupational-therapy driving eval after the trip").

Add a clause stating you judge he poses an imminent, high risk of a serious crash on this specific trip despite counseling (e.g., due to significant hearing loss/visual impairment and recent concussion), and that reporting is the only available immediate harm-reduction measure.

Add one concrete indicator of elevated public-safety risk despite normal exam (e.g., "his wife reports two near-misses in the last month" or "he recently got lost and drove into oncoming traffic"), so the justice tradeoff (public safety vs disproportionate loss of mobility in a rural area) is clearer.

data.vignette: An 87-year-old man is seen several weeks after a minor concussion from a low-speed crash. He reports no headaches, dizziness, or confusion. Mini-Cog is normal. His gait and neurologic exam are normal. The police report noted the other driver ran a stop sign, and he was not cited. He has glaucoma and recently met the state’s minimum vision standard with corrective lenses. He wears hearing aids but still has severe hearing loss. He has no prior crashes or moving violations, but he reports two recent near-misses while merging and at a stop-controlled intersection. He usually drives in daylight, but he plans a long solo highway trip this weekend. No on-road driving evaluation or DMV road test is available before then. You judge his near-term crash risk on this trip is high despite counseling, and reporting is the only available immediate harm-reduction measure. He refuses to delay the trip, use a driver, or allow you to contact family. In your state, physician reporting is permitted but not required, and good-faith reporting has legal protection. Reporting would likely trigger immediate license suspension pending review. He lives rurally with limited transportation for food, medications, and medical visits. The soonest occupational-therapy driving evaluation would be after the weekend. He also says he would stop coming to clinic if you report him.

choice_1.choice: Report the driving-safety concern to the licensing authority now

choice_2.choice: Do not report and manage with counseling and urgent referral

You judge his near-term crash risk on this trip is high despite counseling, and reporting is the only available immediate harm-reduction measure. He refuses to delay the trip, use a driver, or allow you to contact family. In your state, physician reporting is permitted but not required, and good-faith reporting has legal protection. Reporting would likely trigger immediate license suspension pending review. He lives rurally with limited transportation for food, medications, and medical visits. The soonest occupational-therapy driving evaluation would be after the weekend. He also says he would stop coming to clinic if you report him.

choice_2.choice: Do not report and manage with counseling and urgent referral
